title: Jungle Cruise — Emily Blunt and Dwayne Johnson on a buoyant ride
text:
Nominally, according to its end credits, Jungle Cruise is based on the 66-year-old Disneyland boat ride, a low-intensity, narrative-free, grandparent-friendly experience wherein the passengers pootle past an assortment of animatronic animals while the skipper lays down a steady stream of puns and Christmas cracker jokes. But, taking a meta-conceptual film-making approach, this lavishly budgeted feature is also, in a sense, based on another Disney-ride-to-film adaptation, Pirates of the Caribbean.

Like its buccaneering exemplar, Jungle Cruise blends period trappings (it is set during the second world war), exoticism, a sprinkling of supernatural CGI fairy dust, and a very on-Disney-brand taste for mechanics-based slapstick. The characters are forever fiddling with widgets to unlock whatchamacallits or activating pulleys and machines to escape villains or steal things.

Emily Blunt stars as plucky scientist Lily Houghton (there's a wry running gag about people being perpetually shocked to see a woman in trousers that somehow gets funnier through excessive repetition). Lily is determined to find a blossom tree in the Amazon rainforest that can cure all manner of ills, and drags along her sweetly effete brother MacGregor (Jack Whitehall), another one of Disney's only-just-gay characters (the coding obvious only to adults). They are guided by Dwayne Johnson's salty sea-dog skipper Frank.

Partly written by Glenn Ficarra and John Requa, the secret weapons of many a fine Hollywood comedy (Bad Santa; Crazy, Stupid, Love), this is a much funnier, more buoyant movie than you might expect. The extra lime in its caipirinha is the casting of an assortment of outstanding character actors in supporting roles, including Jesse Plemons, Paul Giamatti and Édgar Ramírez as a heavy called Aguirre, the name tipping a plumed conquistador hat towards Werner Herzog's Amazon-set classic Aguirre, the Wrath of God.

★★★☆☆

In cinemas worldwide from July 30
